Rogue-lites: Hades

08/03/2021

James Lees looks at one of 2020's highest-rated games, Hades. But is it the ultimate Rogue-lite?

Image by Hades, Supergiant Games.

By Elie Gould

Supergiant Games is in many regards â€˜theâ€™ indie games developer. Bastion, their debut game in 2011, rocketed into stardom with its reactive voice-over, smart narrative and solid gameplay, where it remains one of the original indie classics along with the likes of Braid and Limbo. But Supergiant have never made the same game twice and whilst their later games Transistor and Pyre didnâ€™t quite hit the same level, they are each stunning in their own right. If thereâ€™s one thread that ties Supergiant games together, then itâ€™s the narrative core. It doesnâ€™t matter if theyâ€™re doing a half-turn-based combat high concept sci-fi adventure in the clouds, or a strange occult basketball tournament, the gameplay (as good as it always is) comes second to the story, world and characters. So, with that in mind, they made the insane decision of making a game in one of the most mechanic focused genres â€“ the Rouge-Lite.

Originally released as an Early-Access Epic Games Exclusive in 2019, it was largely glossed over until the full release (including on Steam) in September 2020. From there it exploded, becoming the second-highest-rated game on Steam (after Portal 2) and sweeping almost all of the game awards that year.

Playing the game itâ€™s not hard to see why it was so highly rated â€“Â  Hades does everything right. The combat is visceral, colourful and satisfying. Each run can be truly different from the last, thanks to the selection of weapons that can be upgraded in a variety of different ways and the different chains of buff that can be granted to you by the gods of Olympus. Not only that, but the areas will change up too, offering slightly but significantly different bosses and different enemy types which keeps the game interesting even as your amount of dungeon runs creep up to triple digits.

Hades takes the gradual treadmill of unlocks and expands on it. Every time you think you might be coming close to topping out your power you discover something else new, from secret weapon aspects to run changing artefacts. It gives you enough time to get to grips with your steadily increasing options before giving you the next set, and in doing so epitomises the joy of the Rogue-Lite unlock.

But excelling in the two core features of a Rogue-Lite â€“ the combat and progression â€“ just wasnâ€™t enough for Supergiant. They also had to go and add one of the best narratives there is. This narrative follows Zagreus son of the titular god as he attempts to escape the Greek afterlife to seek his mother and rejoin his Olympian brethren. To write properly on the story would take an entire essay, but suffice to say, it manages not only to provide a well-rounded plot in an interesting world but also crucially weaves in the gameplay. Each run is another of Zagreusâ€™ escape attempts and what he does has real consequences for him and those he meets.

The standout (as is Supergiantâ€™s modus operandi) is the characters. Whilst obviously heavily inspired by Greek myth, all the characters are fully fleshed out and believable. They feel like they live lives beyond simply being enemies or allies. They have relationships with one another and whilst you are of course important you are not everything. Dying and going back to the beginning is hardly a penalty when it means there will be new interactions and conversations. The developers' love for the source material is also clearly evident. Zagreus himself is a relatively obscure figure and there are plenty of references to his various iterations throughout the game (Greek mythology is a bit of a mess and most gods have at least several major different versions of them which were worshipped at different times, Iâ€™d advise looking it up â€“ thereâ€™s plenty of weeds to get lost in).

Hades then succeeds on all fronts. If you want to ignore the story and smack around some ancient Greek baddies then there is no better way to do it. The progression system takes and refines everything that has come before, giving it an almost addictive quality. That twinned with the compelling characters the game keeps you coming back for more.

Of course, there will be no â€˜Hades 2â€™; at least not one made by Supergiant Games. They have come into the genre and set a new high bar and, like before, they will move on to something new and wonderful. The hope is that theyâ€™ve shown how it can be done and others will be able to run with it, and innovate something new. But for now, at least Hades is perhaps the ultimate Rogue-Lite.
